content:
I do not have the ability to observe the exact process of a sound engineer, so this answer is based on common approaches in music production. 

when mixing different vocal tracks to create a cohesive sound for the chorus, a sound engineer may start by ensuring that all the vocals are in tune and time with one another. they may use pitch correction software or manually adjust the pitch of the vocals. 

next, the sound engineer may apply equalization (eq) to the different vocal tracks to remove any unwanted frequencies and to highlight the best qualities of each voice. they may also use compression to ensure that the volume level of the vocals is consistent throughout the chorus. 

once the vocals are balanced and treated with eq and compression, the sound engineer may begin to pan different vocal tracks in the stereo field to create a sense of depth and space in the mix. 

lastly, the sound engineer may add reverb, delay or other effects in order to blend the different vocal tracks together and make them sound as if they were all recorded at the same time. 

throughout the process, the sound engineer may make adjustments to the mix until the different vocal tracks sound like a cohesive unit with a clear, defined sound.
